entry.title: Combined summary - Libre/Open blockchain / cryptographic ASICs
entry.summary: The article discusses various challenges and vulnerabilities in designing ASICs for Bitcoin mining and hardware wallet key protection, as well as efforts to create transparently-openly-developed ASICs with a full audit trail and mathematical Formal Correctness Proofs. The conversation between ZmnSCPxj and Luke revolves around the challenges of designing digital ASICs, specifically in relation to hardware wallet ASICs. They discuss the use of formal correctness proofs for netlist to RTL equivalence and simulation testing for RTL correctness. Additionally, the conversation touches on tool licensing costs and recommendations for using multiple vendors, as well as the challenges of working with foundries and reducing risk.In another conversation, ZmnSCPxj highlights that increasing power efficiency does not reduce the amount of actual energy consumed by Bitcoin mining since rational miners will pack more miners in the same number of watts rather than reduce their watt consumption. This logic also applies to purchasing decisions for beowulf clusters. The inherent "arms race" in Bitcoin mining results in very few players being able to create Bitcoin mining ASICs at all, which could leave the entirety of Bitcoin open to hardware backdoors.Furthermore, the article discusses the vulnerability of ASICs in test modes, especially when key material is loaded into registers or caches. An attacker can control the CPU clock and scan mode, thus making it possible to exfiltrate data from the scan chain registers, even if the chip is unable to execute algorithms. The risk can be mitigated by designing state machines that force unused states into known states and using flash memory to periodically reload flip-flops that hold settings. However, the vulnerability remains, which makes being excessively cautious for cryptographic chips a necessity.The author of the text has experience designing digital ASICs but is limited to larger geometries and in SystemVerilog. They suggest that smaller geometries are only necessary if high performance/unit cost and performance/energy consumption ratios are required. The LibreSOC Project is focused on creating transparently-openly-developed ASICs that can perform cryptographic tasks, such as mining and hardware wallet key protection with mathematical Formal Correctness Proofs. The project has received funding from NLnet and applied for the program "Assure," which was granted a new EU Horizon Grant. However, the costs involved in producing ASICs are high, ranging from â‚¬1,750 for 20 samples of 350nm ASICs to USD 20 million for a 7nm Custom ASIC. Nonetheless, the author believes it is possible to create lower geometry ASICs if there is a compelling reason or sufficient funds.Lastly, the article includes an email conversation between two individuals discussing using scan mode for masking and provides a code snippet to demonstrate how this can be done. The circuit includes a gating register, which is used to prevent glitches during normal operation. Pavol "stick" Rusnak expressed excitement about Luke's efforts and mentioned that their company had spun off a new entity called Tropic Square, which shares the goal of bringing open security chips to the general public.
